bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 162, Number 62 (Thursday, April 21, 2016)]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. NEWHOUSE:H.R. 5017.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:The Property Clause of Article IV, Section 3--The Congressshall have the Power to dispose of and make all needful rulesand regulation respecting the Territory or other Propertybelonging to the United States.[Page H1923]

item.title: National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2017

latestAction.text: Received in the Senate. Read twice. Placed on Senate Legislative Calendar under General Orders. Calendar No. 502.

item.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Readiness.
Referred to the House Committee on Armed Services.
Sponsor introductory remarks on measure. (CR E572)

summary.text:
Port of Benton Restriction Release Act of 2016

This bill authorizes the Department of Transportation, acting through the Maritime Administration, to release all remaining right, title, and interest of the United States in and to a certain parcel of real property (including any improvements thereon) in Richland, Washington, to the Port of Benton, Washington.

bill.title: Port of Benton Restriction Release Act of 2016

item.title: Port of Benton Restriction Release Act of 2016

To direct the Secretary of Transportation, acting through the Maritime Administrator, to release all remaining right, title, and interest of the United States in and to a parcel of real property in Richland, Washington, to the Port of Benton.
Port of Benton Restriction Release Act of 2016

latestAction.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Readiness.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
